title: (x) "Madeline and The Gypsies" brush-like lettering - similar to Cartoon Bold {Mike F}
content:
But i have seen it so much im sure its been turned into a font . Dose anyone know what it is ???

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203221208im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/whatsthisfont_5171.jpg)

 [‹ Anybody know were to get these ornaments?](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203221208/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41076 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) "Maison belle" detergent bottle label - hand lettered {Antonio Cavedoni} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203221208/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41064 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Pogo

comments.content:
The italic weights of Montara are similar:

[http://typedesign.com/fontlist06.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203221208/http:/typedesign.com/fontlist06.html "http://typedesign.com/fontlist06.html")

FF sale is good but alittle too contemp  
think its time is dust off the brush

thank very much tho
If you’ve got a brush and the skills, by all means use ’em!

That lettering brought to my mind immediately Cartoon Bold (Howard Allen Trafton, 1936). I don’t know why no one has made a mainstream digital version of this, because it is still seen in use all the time.

There _are_ digital version out there, including David Rakowski’s [Adineski Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203221208/http:/www.faces.co.uk/fonts/Intecsas/Adineski-Bold-IN20125/), Fontbank’s [Caricature](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203221208/http:/www.buyfonts.com/value_for_money/caricature.htm) and Cancun on CorelDraw CDs.
